Definition: In this task, a passage will be given and the goal is to identify an event from the passage. An event is defined as a single word representing something that happened, is happening, or may happen. An event can be factual or hypothetical, positive or negative, certain or uncertain. While most events are based on verbs, an event can also be based on a noun (ex. storm, snow, rainfall) or a copula verb (is, was, been, etc.). The event must not be a pronoun or an adjective. For noun events with multiple words, use the last word in the phrase as event.

Positive Examples.input: Passage: I submitted the hit. The hit was approved, and then I was paid.
Positive Examples.explanation: There are three events in this passage (i) submission event ("submitted") (ii) the approval event ("approved"), and (iii) the payment event ("paid"). You can use any one of them as an output.

Positive Examples.input: Passage: He was caught in the snow storm.
Positive Examples.explanation: There are two events in this passage (i) he was caught ("caught") and (ii) the snow storm event ("storm"). You can use any one of them as an output. Since snow storm is a noun event with multiple words, we only use the last word 'storm' as an event.

Positive Examples.input: Passage: He is on the east coast.
Positive Examples.explanation: The copula "is" an event describing his location.

Positive Examples.input: Passage: He wanted to finish the task.
Positive Examples.explanation: There are two events in this passage (i) he wanted to do something ("wanted") and (ii) finish the task ("finish"). Either of wanted or finish can be used as output. However note that though there is an uncertainty about the task i.e. indeed finished or not, "finish" is still a valid event.

Positive Examples.input: Passage: If he works hard, then he will finish the task.
Positive Examples.explanation: There are two events in this passage (i) he works hard ("works") and (ii) he will finish the task. ("finish"). You can use either of works or finish as an output. Here the second event happens only if the first one is true, but both are considered as events. This is an example of hypothetical event.

Negative Examples.explanation: Happy is an adjective and hence cannot be an event. The output should be "is" which represents an event describing his attribute of happiness.

Negative Examples.input: Passage: He was caught in the elevator.
Negative Examples.explanation: Not every noun can be an event. Here "elevator" is an object and one cannot say "an elevator happened" hence it is not an event. "caught" is a correct output.

Negative Examples.input: Passage: The flu season is winding down.
Negative Examples.explanation: The "flu season" is a noun events with multiple words, but only last word "season" sould be used as an event as per definition.

Negative Examples.input: Passage: The death toll climbed up to 99 soon after the explosion.
Negative Examples.explanation: There are two events in this passage "climbed" and "explosion". Though blast is a synonym of explosion, it is not present in the passage. The output must contain events that are present in the passage.
